objectDesc.extent:
278 mm x 174 mm (dimensions of all - size of leaves).
225-232 mm x 123-126 mm (dimensions of Booklet A - size of written space).
objectDesc.layoutDescription: Some pricking is visible and all ruling is in hardpoint.

handDesc.summary: The scribble in Old English is by a s. xi/xii hand. Latin items were written by many hands in minuscule script of s. xi/xii.

hands.name: Scribble
hands.description: fol. i.r. A scribble, 'of searbyrig ic eom'

characters.note: Caroline a with a very short head.
Insular g, its loop closes with a hairline.
Insular r, with its descender of the second r curves to the left.
Caroline short s, finishes on the writing line.

history.provenance: According to Ker (1957, p. 143), 'the manuscript was, no doubt, at Salisbury from about the time of the first establishment of canons there by St. Osmund' (Bishop of Salisbury 1078-1099). It was catalogued as no. 160 Vita et miracula S. Andreae in Patrick Young's catalogue, 1622 (Lucas 1997, p. 11).
history.acquisition: The manuscript was borrowed by James Ussher (1581-1656), archbishop of Armagh, on 30th September 1640 according to a memorandum kept in Salisbury. Ussher did not return the book: 'supposedly it was lost in the looting of his home at Chelsea in 1643' (Lucas 1997, p. 11). It came to Trinity College through Ussher.

admin: Described by Takako Kato with the assistance of Hollie Morgan and Johanna Green, with reference to published scholarship (2010; 2013).
